text: now for almost 50 years sir paul
mccartney has been blamed for breaking
up the beatles but in a new bbc
interview he said the split was actually
initiated by john lennon here's more
from our music correspondent mark savage
sir paul has been shouldering the blame
for breaking up the beatles since 1970
and there's two reasons for that first
of all he was the first person to
acknowledge that the band were on a
brick in a press release for his debut
album which came out that year and in
that he said that he couldn't foresee a
time when he would ever work with john
lennon again and then later that year he
sued the rest of the band to dissolve
their business relationship so really
since then fans and scholars have
assumed that it was sir paul who
instigated the breakup of the beatles
but in a new interview for radio 4's
this cultural life program he said
that's not the case
i'm not the person who instigated the
split you brought the lawyers in there
didn't he oh no no no john walked into
the room one day and said i'm leaving
the beatles and he said it's quite
thrilling it's rather like a divorce
and then we were left to pick up the
pieces
but i didn't instigate the split
that was our journey
so paul went on to say in the interview
that john lennon wanted to spend more
time with yoko ono and staging his
famous peace protests and certainly we
know that john missed the last ever full
recording session of the beatles in 1970
because he was on holiday with yoko but
the interesting thing that came at the
end of this interview is that sir paul
said that if john hadn't walked away
then the beatles would have continued to
make albums
